description: Comprehensive Calculus concepts covering limits, derivatives, and integrals

definition.text: A limit describes the value that a function approaches as the input approaches some value. Limits are fundamental to calculus, forming the basis for derivatives and integrals. We write lim(x→a) f(x) = L if f(x) gets arbitrarily close to L as x approaches a.

keyFormulas.name: Limit Notation
keyFormulas.meaning: f(x) approaches L as x approaches a

keyFormulas.name: Sum Rule
keyFormulas.formula: lim[f(x) + g(x)] = lim f(x) + lim g(x)
keyFormulas.meaning: Limit of sum equals sum of limits

keyFormulas.name: Product Rule
keyFormulas.formula: lim[f(x) · g(x)] = lim f(x) · lim g(x)
keyFormulas.meaning: Limit of product equals product of limits

examples.question: Find lim(x→∞) (3x² + 2)/(x² + 5)

steps.action: Divide numerator and denominator by x²
As x → ∞, terms with x² in denominator → 0

examples.verification: Ratio of leading coefficients for polynomials of equal degree

realWorldApplications.title: Instantaneous Velocity
realWorldApplications.description: Velocity is the limit of average velocity as time interval approaches zero

definition.text: The derivative of a function represents its instantaneous rate of change. Geometrically, it gives the slope of the tangent line at any point. If y = f(x), then the derivative f'(x) = lim(h→0) [f(x+h) - f(x)]/h.

keyFormulas.name: Power Rule
keyFormulas.meaning: Derivative of x to any power n

keyFormulas.name: Constant Rule
keyFormulas.meaning: Derivative of a constant is zero

keyFormulas.name: Sum Rule
keyFormulas.meaning: Derivative of sum is sum of derivatives

keyFormulas.name: Trigonometric Derivatives
keyFormulas.formula:
d/dx[sin x] = cos x
d/dx[cos x] = -sin x

examples.question: Find the derivative of f(x) = 3x⁴ - 5x² + 2x - 7

steps.action: Apply power rule to each term

examples.verification: Each term follows power rule correctly

examples.question: Find the derivative of f(x) = x² · sin(x)
Find the derivative of f(x) = (2x + 1)⁵

steps.explanation: Power rule for outer, derivative of inner
Multiply outer derivative by inner derivative

examples.verification: Chain rule: derivative of outer times derivative of inner

proofOfConcept.theorem: Derivative of x² from First Principles

realWorldApplications.title: Physics - Velocity
realWorldApplications.description: Velocity is the derivative of position: v = ds/dt

realWorldApplications.title: Economics - Marginal Cost
realWorldApplications.description: Marginal cost is the derivative of total cost function

definition.text: Integration is the reverse process of differentiation. The definite integral of a function gives the signed area under its curve. The indefinite integral (antiderivative) finds a function whose derivative is the given function.

keyFormulas.name: Indefinite Integral
keyFormulas.meaning: Where F'(x) = f(x) and C is constant

keyFormulas.name: Power Rule for Integration
keyFormulas.meaning: Reverse of power rule for derivatives

keyFormulas.name: Trigonometric Integrals
keyFormulas.formula:
∫sin x dx = -cos x + C
∫cos x dx = sin x + C

keyFormulas.name: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
keyFormulas.meaning: Derivative of integral returns original function

steps.action: Integrate each term using power rule

examples.question: Evaluate ∫₀² x²dx
examples.verification: This represents area under y = x² from 0 to 2

steps.action: Let u = 2x, then du = 2dx, so dx = du/2

realWorldApplications.title: Economics - Consumer Surplus
realWorldApplications.description: Area between demand curve and price line

definition.text: Differentiation rules are systematic methods for finding derivatives. The basic rules include the power rule, product rule, quotient rule, and chain rule. These rules can be combined to differentiate almost any function.

keyFormulas.name: Constant Rule
keyFormulas.meaning: Derivative of a constant is zero

keyFormulas.name: Product Rule
keyFormulas.meaning: Derivative of first times second + first times derivative of second

keyFormulas.name: Quotient Rule
keyFormulas.meaning: Low d-high minus high d-low over low squared

keyFormulas.name: Chain Rule
keyFormulas.meaning: Derivative of outer times derivative of inner

steps.action: Apply power rule and sum rule term by term

examples.question: Find d/dx[x² · sin x] using product rule

steps.action: Identify f = x², g = sin x

examples.verification: Can be factored as x(2 sin x + x cos x)

examples.question: Find d/dx[(3x + 1)⁵] using chain rule
examples.verification: Chain rule: derivative of outside × derivative of inside

steps.action: Identify as composite: sin(u) where u = x²

definition.text: Derivatives have numerous applications including finding rates of change, optimization (maxima and minima), related rates, curve sketching, and linear approximation. Critical points occur where f'(x) = 0 or is undefined.

keyFormulas.name: First Derivative Test
keyFormulas.formula: f' changes + to - → max; f' changes - to + → min
keyFormulas.meaning: Sign change determines type of extremum

keyFormulas.name: Second Derivative Test
keyFormulas.meaning: Concavity determines type at critical point

keyFormulas.name: Concavity
keyFormulas.formula: f'' > 0: concave up (∪); f'' < 0: concave down (∩)

examples.question: Find the maximum value of f(x) = -x² + 4x + 5

steps.action: Verify it's a maximum using second derivative
steps.result: f''(x) = -2 < 0, so x = 2 is a maximum

examples.verification: Parabola opens down (a = -1 < 0), so vertex is max ✓

examples.question: A farmer has 200 m of fence. What dimensions maximize the area of a rectangular pen with one side along a barn?

steps.action: Set up: Let x = width (two sides), y = length (one side)
Express A in terms of x

examples.finalAnswer: Width = 50 m, Length = 100 m, Max Area = 5000 m²

definition.text: Beyond basic antiderivatives, integration techniques include substitution (reverse chain rule), integration by parts (reverse product rule), partial fractions, and trigonometric substitution. These methods handle complex integrals.

keyFormulas.name: Integration by Parts
keyFormulas.meaning: LIATE rule: Log, Inverse trig, Algebraic, Trig, Exponential

examples.question: Find ∫x·eˣ dx using integration by parts

steps.action: Choose u and dv using LIATE
steps.explanation: A comes before E in LIATE

steps.action: Let u = x + 1, then du = dx

definition.text: A definite integral computes the signed area between a function and the x-axis over an interval [a, b]. The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus connects definite integrals with antiderivatives. Unlike indefinite integrals, definite integrals have no '+ C'.

keyFormulas.name: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (Part 2)
keyFormulas.meaning: F is any antiderivative of f

keyFormulas.name: Fundamental Theorem (Part 1)
keyFormulas.meaning: Derivative of integral is the integrand

keyFormulas.name: Properties
keyFormulas.formula: ∫ᵃᵇ f = -∫ᵇᵃ f, ∫ᵃᵃ f = 0, ∫ᵃᵇ cf = c∫ᵃᵇ f

examples.question: Find the average value of f(x) = x² on [0, 3]
examples.verification: The horizontal line y = 3 has same area as curve

definition.text: The area between two curves y = f(x) and y = g(x) from x = a to x = b is found by integrating the difference of the functions. Always subtract the lower function from the upper function.

keyFormulas.name: Area Between Curves
keyFormulas.meaning: Use absolute value or determine which is on top

examples.question: Find area between y = x² and y = x from x = 0 to x = 1

definition.text: When a region is rotated around an axis, it creates a 3D solid. The volume can be found using disk/washer method (slicing perpendicular to axis) or shell method (cylindrical shells).

keyFormulas.name: Disk Method
keyFormulas.meaning: R(x) = radius from axis to curve

keyFormulas.name: Washer Method
keyFormulas.meaning: Outer radius R, inner radius r

examples.question: Find volume when y = √x is rotated about x-axis from x = 0 to x = 4

steps.result: V = π∫₀⁴ (√x)² dx = π∫₀⁴ x dx

realWorldApplications.title: Manufacturing
realWorldApplications.description: Volume of turned objects on a lathe

definition.text: Related rates problems involve finding the rate of change of one quantity given the rate of change of another related quantity. Use implicit differentiation with respect to time, treating all changing quantities as functions of t.

examples.question: A 10-ft ladder leans against a wall. The base slides away at 2 ft/s. How fast is the top sliding down when base is 6 ft from wall?

definition.text: L'Hôpital's Rule helps evaluate limits with indeterminate forms (0/0 or ∞/∞) by differentiating numerator and denominator separately. Apply repeatedly if needed.

keyFormulas.name: L'Hôpital's Rule
keyFormulas.formula: If lim f(x)/g(x) = 0/0 or ∞/∞, then lim f(x)/g(x) = lim f'(x)/g'(x)

examples.question: Find lim(x→0) (sin x)/x
examples.verification: This is a fundamental limit in calculus

examples.question: Find lim(x→∞) x²/eˣ
examples.verification: eˣ grows faster than any polynomial

definition.text: An infinite series is the sum of infinitely many terms. A series converges if its partial sums approach a finite limit. Tests for convergence include comparison, ratio, root, integral, and alternating series tests.

keyFormulas.name: Ratio Test
keyFormulas.formula: L = lim|aₙ₊₁/aₙ|: converges if L < 1, diverges if L > 1

examples.question: Determine if Σ(n=1 to ∞) n/2ⁿ converges

definition.text: Taylor series represent functions as infinite polynomials centered at a point a. Maclaurin series are Taylor series centered at 0. Important series include eˣ, sin x, cos x, and ln(1+x).

examples.question: Use first 4 terms of eˣ to approximate e⁰·⁵
